response.answer_text: We have analysed that a couple of years back when we decided to start our stock investor portal (Stock and Index Ratings for long-term stock investing). We found the following information:  That's 60 million in the US. Not all of them trade in stocks directly. 33.6% hold stocks directly, 37.8% in retirement accounts which can be funds, too. If we assume 33.6% of the 37.8% in retirement accounts, we come up with around half of the 60 million families holding stocks. That's 30 million in the US. The rest of the world is a lot less keen on stocks. Let's assume they hold another 30 million. That makes 70 million people who hold publicly traded stocks directly in 2009. It's probably near 80-90 million today.
